item.title: [cssom-1] CSSImportRule appears twice in the sidebar
item.content:encoded:

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The CSSImportRule entry should appear only once.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

item.title: [css-transforms-2] transform-style docs should mention that there are scenarios where the value is forced
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform-style

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

It is not mentioned that there are scenarios where the flat will be used even when preserve-3d has been specified.

What did you expect to see?

It should mention that other CSS properties (such as overflow: hidden;) may force the transform-style value to flat.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

For properties that force flat to be used, see
https://www.w3.org/TR/css-transforms-2/#grouping-property-values

item.title: [css-images-3] Outdated note for `image-rendering`
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/image-rendering

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

  1. There's a note below the BCD table that claims Firefox does not support the pixelated value, but it does since Firefox 93 (see the Mozilla bug).
  2. This note should be placed at the end of the "Values" subsection.
  3. Is it necessary to expose so many details about the implementions in the note to the general audience?
  4. The "See also" section has a link to the page itself.

What did you expect to see?

Either the note be updated and relocated, or be removed all together.

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=856337#c57

item.title: [web-animations-2] KeyframeEffect.target: issues with the example
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/KeyframeEffect/target

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

examples

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The white rabbit example should be a transition, not an animation: The ears go from visible to not. You don’t need an animation for that, just a class change.

Let's say we stick with that anyhow, there are other issues.

The code in the code example:

// returns <div id="rabbit">Click the rabbit's ears!</div>
rabbitDownKeyframes.target;

Is not included in the linked Codepen.
If the user wants to add it by copying and pasting, the line itself isn’t a log or a variable definition. it just sits there.

Additionally, the example is not good UX. The sighted user has no way of knowing where to click or even that they should. There are no focusable / interactive html elements. The cursor doesn't indicate clickability either.

What did you expect to see?

in page example. If not, a link to a working example that includes the API component being discussed

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [css-logical-1] The `max-block-size` page significantly deviates from other logical sizing properties
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/max-block-size

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Comparing to the pages for other logical sizing properties (e.g. min-block-size), the content of this page contains a lot of details on how to use this property for specific purposes and how writing modes affect the mapping, which makes the page more like a simple tutorial instead of a technical doc.

What did you expect to see?

The content of this property be aligned with other logical sizing properties.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

This inconsistency appeared during the localization of this page, so it would be better to see if it can be resolved before the localization starts.

item.title: [css-logical-1, css-page-4] Should `page-break-*` be explicitly mark as deprecated?
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/page-break-after

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Currently there's only a simple warning on the page-break-after and page-break-before pages saying that these properties have been renamed to break-after and break-before. However, CSS Fragmentation Module Level 3 (where break-* are defined) says that page-break-* must be treated as legacy shorthands for break-*. So it seems better to place an explicit deprecation note on the page-break-* pages.

What did you expect to see?

A deprecation note for each page-break-* property.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

CSS Fragmentation Module Level 3:
https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-break/#page-break-properties
The relevant item in the change history in the spec:
https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-break/#change-2018-aliasing

Do you have anything more you want to share?

The Chrome Platform Status shows that page-break-* (e.g. page-break-after) has significantly higher usage than break-* (e.g. break-after), which might be due to the fact that the former two properties have been supported since the early days of modern browsers.

item.title: [css-sizing-4, css-conditional-3, css-sizing-3] In correct statement about max-width
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/max-width

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

The Into and "Try it"

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The max-width CSS property sets the maximum width of an element. It prevents the used value of the width property from becoming larger than the value specified by max-width.

max-width overrides width, but min-width overrides max-width.

Although true a lot of the time, its not technically true all the time. The exceptions is what makes debugging code so hard. It might be worth adding a note for when this is not true, like with select inputs, width overrides max-width.

What did you expect to see?

Information to help explain why max-width is not working on a <select> input.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://stackoverflow.com/a/10795269/5506400

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Hope one day form controls will be more consistent with their API. Every form control has some weird quirks one has to work around.

item.title: [filter-effects-2] SVG contrast filter
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Element/filter

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

There's no contrast filter page

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The SVG {{SVGElement("filter")}} element is used to define custom filter effects that can then be referenced by {{htmlattrxref("id")}}. The <filter>'s {{SVGElement("feComponentTransfer")}} primitive enables pixel-level color remapping. To alter the contrast, include linear {{SVGElement("feFuncR")}} (red), {{SVGElement("feFuncB")}} (blue), and {{SVGElement("feFuncG")}} (green) primitives with the slope attribute value defining the contrast multiplier and the intercept attribute.

<svg role="none">
  <filter id="contrast">
    <feComponentTransfer>
      <feFuncR type="linear" slope="[amount]" intercept="-(0.5 * [amount]) + 0.5"/>
      <feFuncG type="linear" slope="[amount]" intercept="-(0.5 * [amount]) + 0.5"/>
      <feFuncB type="linear" slope="[amount]" intercept="-(0.5 * [amount]) + 0.5"/>
    </feComponentTransfer>
  </filter>
</svg>

Given the above, the following two statements will produce the same results

.filter {
  filter: contrast(2);
}
.filter {
  filter: url(#contrast);
}

To create a filter that doubles the original contrast, we set the slope attribute to 2, for 200%, and the intercept attribute set to the -(0.25 * [2.00]) + 0.5, which is -0.5.

<svg role="none">
  <filter id="contrast">
    <feComponentTransfer>
      <feFuncR type="linear" slope="2" intercept="-0.5"/>
      <feFuncG type="linear" slope="2" intercept="-0.5"/>
      <feFuncB type="linear" slope="2" intercept="-0.5"/>
    </feComponentTransfer>
  </filter>
</svg>

What did you expect to see?

A page where including the above would makes sense.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [cssom-view-1] Incorrect image format used to demonstrate pixel quality
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/devicePixelRatio

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Correcting resolution in a

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The example with writing "I love MDN" on a green box is blurry.

What did you expect to see?

A high-quality image. You can't display a quality simple two-color image using jpeg lossy compression! This should be png format instead.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

Adobe and many others says about using png

They’re often the default format for screenshot images since they can provide a highly accurate representation of your desktop and don’t compress pixels together. A huge color palette and lossless compression ensure they retain plenty of detail — making them a popular choice for illustrations and charts.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Here is an example zoomed in Photoshop. You can see the typical jpeg "fuzz" around the letters and the general noise in the image. The image on the right, if png, would be razor sharp! Or at least with png at most would be some anti-aliasing edges. Be sure to view this full-size, not the size in the box shown here (click on it with a big terminal window)

Given it's a graphic, and I'm new to MDN, I don't feel comfortable providing an alternate png file.


full-size

item.title: [css-images-3] Description of image-rendering algorithms do not follow the W3C specs
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/image-rendering

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Values

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The values crisp-edges and pixelated are too specific.
It says that crisp-edges uses nearest neighbour scaling, but the W3C spec reads:

The image must be scaled with an algorithm that preserves contrast and edges in the image, and which does not smooth colors or introduce blur to the image in the process. This is intended for images such as pixel art or line drawings.

For pixelated, there's a description of how two steps are used in the rendering, first nearest neighbour to the nearest greater integer multiple scale, then a smooth render pass to render down to the actual intended scale. However, the W3C spec reads:

The image must be scaled with the "nearest neighbor" or similar algorithm, to preserve a "pixelated" look as the image changes in size.

I.e. nearest neighbour rendering is only mentioned for pixelated rendering, but even there, it's not a required algorithm, nor is there any mention of what steps are to be taken for non-integer multiples (and nearest neighbour scaling works best for powers of two, not any arbitrary choice of integer values).

What did you expect to see?

I was expecting to see the W3C spec descriptions, or a variation describing the same results. The current description is too specific and does not describe actual browser implementations. Otherwise crisp-edges and pixelated should look the same across rendering engines, but crisp edges look much worse in Gecko than Blink.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#valdef-image-rendering-crisp-edges
https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#valdef-image-rendering-pixelated

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [cssom-1] JS names for CSS properties
item.content:encoded:

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The text includes this important statement:

CSS property values may be accessed using the getPropertyValue(propName) API or by indexing directly into the object such as obj['z-index'] or obj.zIndex.

Which likely deserves it's own page.

What did you expect to see?

A link to a document describing https://drafts.csswg.org/cssom/#css-property-to-idl-attribute or, possibly,

let availableProps = getComputedStyle(document.body);
let list = [];
for(cssProp in availableProps) { 
  if(!/\-/.test(cssProp) && /^[a-z]/.test(cssProp)) {
    list.push(cssProp);
  }
}
console.log(list);

as a live example in the page

item.title: [web-animations-2] "Automatically removing filling animations" and several related docs are incorrect and/or extremely confusing
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Animation#automatically_removing_filling_animations

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Automatically removing filling animations

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

  • Page says "remove" event is fired when animation is put into "active" replace state, but actually after a "remove" event the replace state must be "removed", and "active" is the initial/default state
  • Animation.replaceState page says that "removed" is for when an animation is "explicitly removed", but it's not clear if or how that's possible.
  • The example doesn't actually demonstrate all of the things it claims (for example, it does not print the replace state at any relevant point).
  • Animation.commitStyles() and the aforementioned example claim that the end state is written, but spec says the current state is written; see also #20086
  • probably more things

What did you expect to see?

Clear docs with supporting examples, terminology used in a manner consist with its meaning in the spec?

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

See links above.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

I'm not exactly a subject matter expert here, I might be (am) very confused.

item.title: [css-shadow-parts-1] ::part(): Missing information
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/::part

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

all of it

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

there are tons of limits on using ::part(), not of which are described.

What did you expect to see?

Selecting a Shadow Element: the ::part() pseudo-element

The ::part() pseudo-element allows you to select elements that have been exposed via a part attribute. The syntax is:

::part() = ::part( + )

The ::part() pseudo-element only matches anything when the originating element is a shadow host. If the originating element’s shadow root’s part element map contains all of the specified s, ::part() matches the element or elements keyed to that . Otherwise, it matches nothing.
For example, if you have a custom button that contains a "label" element that is exposed for styling (via part="label"), you can select it with #the-button::part(label).
Part names act similarly to classes: multiple elements can have the same part name, and a single element can have multiple part names.

A tabstrip control might have multiple elements with part="tab", all of which are selected by ::part(tab).

If a single tab is active at a time, it can be specially indicated with part="tab active" and then selected by ::part(tab active) (or ::part(active tab), as order doesn’t matter).

The ::part() pseudo-element can take additional pseudo-classes after it, such as x-button::part(label):hover, but never matches the structural pseudo-classes or any other pseudo-classes that match based on tree information rather than local element information.

The ::part() pseudo-element can also take additional pseudo-elements after it, such as x-button::part(label)::before, but never match additional ::part()s.
For example, x-panel::part(confirm-button)::part(label) never matches anything. This is because doing so would expose more structural information than is intended.

If the ’s internal confirm button had used something like part="label => confirm-label" to forward the button’s internal parts up into the panel’s own part element map, then a selector like x-panel::part(confirm-label) would select just the one button’s label, ignoring any other labels.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-shadow-parts/#part

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [css-shapes-2] Property listed as unsupported on Firefox for Android, but @supports still fires for it
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/shape-image-threshold

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Browser compatibility

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The property is listed as supported on Firefox for Desktop, but unsupported for Firefox for Android, However, the @supports media rule indicates that the property is supported on both platforms.

What did you expect to see?

If the property does not function as intended on Firefox for Android, but still registers as supported when using @supports, then there should be a note of this.

I haven't bothered to see if the property does function as intended on Android. The @supports query is my only use case at present.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

The following properties on other articles have the same issue; this form only lets me report one article at a time and making separate issues for these seems like a waste:

  • overscroll-behavior-block
  • overscroll-behavior-inline

In case the context helps: I need to target smartphones with CSS to offer a touch-friendly layout. The only usable media queries for this task are unreliable in Firefox and apparently have been for four years. I can use @-moz-document url-prefix() to target Firefox in general, but I need some way of targeting the Android version in specific in order to complete my task. I was hoping to find a property I could use @supports on, though that is increasingly seeming like a long shot.

MDN metadata

item.title: [css-fonts-5] getComputedStyle() does not respect the Fallback weights algorithm
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-weight

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

There is missing information that getComputedStyle() on an element with a weight style which the font does not support actually does not return the real shown font weight but the weight style number thus not reflecting the result of the Fallback weights algorithm.

What did you expect to see?

A warning that getComputedStyle() has unintuitive behavior regarding font weight (especially surprising when one uses a variable font which supports "infinite" range of weights like Inter).

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Hacky test code changing font weight based on font size:

  function f( e, x ){
    return Math.trunc( parseInt( window.getComputedStyle( e )['font-weight'], 10 ) *
        // 14 font size => 1.005 font weight coefficient, 32 => 1.11, ...
        ( (Math.abs(x -14) * (1.11 -1.005)/(32 -14) ) +1.005 ) )
  }
  for( const e of document.querySelectorAll( '*, *::after, *::before, *::first-letter, *::first-line, *::selection, *::backdrop' ).values() ){
    try {
      const x = parseFloat( window.getComputedStyle( e )['font-size'] )
      const y = f( e, x )
      e.style.setProperty( 'font-weight',  y, 'important' )
      // not a variable font (or one which does not support fine-grained weight settings)
      // does not work as of 20221123_124058+0100 in newest Chromium
      //if( f() !== y ){
        e.style.setProperty( 'font-family', 'Inter var', 'important' )
      //}
    } catch {}
  }
@font-face {
  font-family: 'Inter var';
  font-style: oblique 0deg 10deg;
  font-weight: 100 900;
  font-display: swap;
  src: url( 'https://rsms.me/font-files/Inter.var.woff2?v=3.19' ) format( 'woff2' );
  font-feature-settings: "zero" 1, "ss01" 1;
}

item.title: [css-logical-1] The article on the CSS float property lists several non-standard values as supported, with no explanation of what they are or where they came from
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/float

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Formal syntax

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The list of valid values for floats includes several values that were never formally adopted into any standards -- specifically, values from the CSS Page Floats draft, last updated in 2015, which isn't linked to or mentioned in the float article.

The following values from that standard are listed in this section but do not work in Firefox or, presumably, any modern browser:

  • top
  • bottom
  • block-start
  • block-end
  • snap-block(...)
  • snap-inline(...)
  • footnote

The following values from the draft standard work in Firefox, but not Chrome or Edge. They are listed on the page with no mention that they're part of the draft standard, and they're not listed in the CSS 2 standard linked to by the page.

  • inline-start
  • inline-end

The browser support section mentions inline-start and inline-end, but not the others, and not the draft standard in general.

What did you expect to see?

Only values that are standardized should be listed.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

CSS Page Floats draft standard defines the values I'm referring to.

CSS 2 float values as linked from the article: no mention of the values I'm referring to.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [cssom-view-1] False claim: window.pageYOffset === window.scrollY; // always true
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollY

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Notes

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The pageYOffset property is an alias for the scrollY property:

window.pageYOffset === window.scrollY; // always true

What did you expect to see?

If not redefined, the scrollY property is an alias for the pageYOffset property. In that case following holds:

window.pageYOffset === window.scrollY; // always true

(I do not know if this makes any sense. See supporting information.)

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

I created some content-scripts on Google Chrome (through Extension) which sets the property window.scrollYto a negative value (which actually was a bug of my content script, but nevertheless it exposed this problem here).

Afterwards window.pageYOffset === window.scrollY was no more true on the content-script,as window.scrollY stayed negative, but window.pageYOffset continued to work as usual.

Also you state, this property is readonly. Whatever this means, because I thought that by assigning to window.scrollY you can create an effect like with window.scrollTo() on Chrome. (Perhaps I am completely wrong here.)

Read:

I really have no idea if this is a bug, a feature, some undocumented part of browser extensions, something browser specific, intended or whatever.

But:

At my side, window.scrollY can be set to something negative (which makes no sense at all) and hence the === becomes false.

This either is a Browser compatibility issue or some lack of documentation. In any way, it should be clearly stated.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Ubuntu 20.04 LTS
Chrome 102.0.5005.115 (Official Build) (64-bit)

item.title: [css-overflow-3] CSS overflow property is giving results inconsistant with guide
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/CSS/Building_blocks/Overflowing_content

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Overflowing Content

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

On this page https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/CSS/Building_blocks/Overflowing_content it gives an example for setting the overflow property to 'scroll' and says "Remove some content from the box below. Notice how the scrollbars remain, even if there is no need for scrolling."

I removed some content but this actually removed the scrollbar (which personally I think is great btw) and contradicts the statement.

I then did some testing on a local html site and indeed the scrollbar only appears when the text does overflow. I checked the CSS specifications and they still recommend displaying a scrollbar whether content overflows or not, so I'm wondering if this browser specific? I am reading the guide and testing in the latest version of Mozilla Firefox.

In this same example, it also states below "In the example above, we only need to scroll on the y axis, however we get scrollbars in both axes. To just scroll on the y axis, you could use the overflow-y property, setting overflow-y: scroll."

But I also do not see any horizontal scrollbar at all.

What did you expect to see?

item.title: [cssom-1] [Web-API] Constructible stylesheets guide
item.content:encoded:
FF101 minimal release work for constructible stylesheets was done in #16411. This covered release notes and new properties.

What still need to be done is to provide an explanation of the API as "guide" material.
IN summary, it's a way to construct a CSS stylesheet programmatically so that it can be shared efficiently with shadow DOM subtrees.

This is mostly likely an addition to https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Web_Components/Using_shadow_DOM and lots of cross linking.

The main methods/properties are:

  • CSSStyleSheet methods including its CSSStyleSheet(), replace, replaceSync, insertRule, deleteRule and adoptedStylesheets in Document and ShadowRoot.

Resources

  • Explainer: https://github.com/WICG/construct-stylesheets/blob/gh-pages/explainer.md

  • Constructable Stylesheets (web.dev)

  • When done, mark this one dev-doc-complete https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1644102

item.title: [css-text-3] `word-break: break-word;` vs `overflow-wrap: anywhere;`
item.content:encoded:

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

break-word is labelled as deprecated, with a note that overflow-wrap: anywhere is equivalent.
While this is true, overflow-wrap: anywhere; still isn't supported by safari, which isn't mentioned anywhere.

What did you expect to see?

I'm not sure exactly how to present this information, but I think the note about word-break: break-word being deprecated should mention:

  • word-break: break-word is deprecated in favor of overflow-wrap: anywhere
  • anywhere is not supported by all browsers, so word-break: break-word should be used instead
  • also consider overflow-wrap: break-word, which behaves similarly

(In my experience, to achieve reasonable text wrapping, you always want either overflow-wrap: anywhere (word-break: break-all) or overflow-wrap: break-word, depending on how you want the intrinsic size to be calculated, so this is a pretty important property to understand)

item.title: [css-conditional-3, DOM-Parsing] Defining page types
item.content:encoded:
Tracking issue for openwebdocs/project#91.

In this project we will aim to:

  • define a complete set of page types for all of MDN's pages
  • document the types in our meta-docs
  • add a front matter items to every page representing its type

The main aim of this is to define types for structured pages - that is, for pages that are always expected to conform to a particular organization. However, I think it will be helpful to have an explicit "guide" type for pages that aren't structured pages.

Scope

In the first part I'd like to understand the scope of this project. The output of this will be a collection of "doc sets" which we will analyze.

A doc set is a group of related pages on MDN - like the JS docs, or the Learn area, and so on.

I'm doing this in a spreadsheet, here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/14RX8EEKPpeYkP2cF5Y_ZKF3JpNJ_24OL7stvZWNJLIY/ .

In the "all doc sets" tab I've listed:

  • all top-level directories under MDN
  • all top-level directories under Web

Each of these, more or less, is a doc set.

I've then asked whether each doc set contains structured content. Doc sets that don't contain structured content are out of scope - they're all "guide" pages.

Then for each doc set that contains structured content I've assigned a priority 1-3. I think for now we should consider the P1 sets, which are:

  • API
  • CSS
  • HTML
  • HTTP
  • JavaScript
  • Learn

The pages in those doc sets are the pages that we will look at for this project.

I think we should execute the project in two phases:

  • defining the page types we want to have
  • adding the page types to the pages

I think we should do all of the analysis first: that is, we should define page types for all doc sets before we update any pages. That's because it is likely that we will end up changing our mind about some definitions as we analyze later doc sets.

Page type definition

So for the first phase we'll define page types for the following doc sets:

  • API: #16255
  • CSS: #15540
  • HTML: #22705
  • HTTP: #22761
  • JavaScript: #16156
  • Learn

Page type implementation

For the second phase we'll add the defined values to the pages.

item.title: [css-contain-2] Containing block via contain:paint vs other alternatives
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/MDN/Contribute/Feedback

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Layout and the containing block

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Regarding Layout and the containing block - CSS: Cascading Style Sheets | MDN,
the list Identifying the containing block includes this for item iv:
A contain value of paint (e.g. contain: paint;)

This is misleading since the "value of paint" is overly specific, suggesting the literal value "paint" is used, and the "(e.g. contain: paint;)" is then confusing because it would be redundant. The reader might be suspicious that there is more to the story, and there is!

What did you expect to see?

Instead of saying "value of paint", it should refer to "Paint containment" with the link to information about other ways to specify a paint containment. The link to contain is also useful since it is more direct, at least for this way of specifying a paint containment. On that page, we find

Note: If applied (with value: paint, strict or content), this property creates:

A new [containing block](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Containing_block) (for the descendants whose [position](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/position) property is absolute or fixed).

So, back to the containing block page, why not say "value of 'paint', 'strict', or 'content'", so people don't have to figure out that a value of 'content' (or 'strict'?) implies the equivalent of a value of 'paint'?

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

MDN documentation is a great service, all the more reason to keep it accurate while being very readable.

I'm not sure about all the other possible ways of affecting the containing block. This problem came up while trying to figure out why position:fixed was not doing what was expected. See Why is my fixed position element not relative to the viewport? - Darren Lester

item.title: [css-fonts-5] Issue with "font-size": recommend to users not to set font-size with "em" units
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-size

A user in the MDN Web Docs Matrix room commented about how the mdn/css-examples repo defines its body font sizes with the em unit (that is, the interactive example at the top of the page).

Using em to define a font size isn't a good practice, because ems are based upon the font size -- in other words, this is setting a font size to...well, relative to the parent's font size. On the body, this isn't as big of an issue, but say you set font-size: 1.25em on something like div, which can have many children: now, each child div is going to have a font size of 125% relative to its parent's font size, creating a constantly-growing font size.

I think that the example shouldn't include an em as one of its default options, especially not as the first option. I also think that we should update the MDN page to include a note at the top to state as such and add a section to explain why.

I found a video that explains why to avoid ems as a font size, which I used as a reference for this.

item.title: [web-animations-2, css-animations-2] Issue with "Element.animate()": wrong scenario mentioned
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/animate
and https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Animations_API/Keyframe_Formats

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

In newer browser versions, you are able to set a beginning or end state for an animation only (i.e. a single keyframe), and the browser will infer the other end of the animation if it is able to.

This mentions two scenarios when only one keyframe is mentioned:

  1. from key frame is inferred. It's the elements current state. The corresponding code snippet covers this case.
  2. to key frame is inferred. In what scenario a browser will be able to infer the end frame given only one frame? Unlike CSS @keyframe rule there are no to and 100% keywords in DOM API. I don't think this scenario is possible. If it is possible, then please provide an example on the pages.
    I think the author is talking about following case:
let rotate360 = [
      { transform: 'rotate(360deg)' },
      {}   // empty keyframe, values are inferred from elements starting state
    ];

But in this case there are two keyframes provided.

Specific section or headline?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/animate#implicit_tofrom_keyframes
and also
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Animations_API/Keyframe_Formats#implicit_tofrom_keyframes

What did you expect to see?

Correct the description saying from frame is inferred if only one keyframe is provided.
Or provide an example for the second scenario.

Did you test this? If so, how?

item.title: [css-lists-3] Issue with "counter-reset": What is the difference in behavior between the latest Firefox (82 or later) and the older 81 or earlier or other browsers?
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/counter-reset

Maybe the page to fix is this: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Counter_Styles/Using_CSS_counters

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

  • (p1) I know that starting with Firefox 82, the behavior of counter-reset has changed from 81 and earlier versions.
    • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1754521
  • (p2) For example, the results of the CSS Demo for counter-reset are different between Firefox (the latest version) and Google Chrome.
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/counter-reset
  • (p3) The ol and ul elements use CSS counter(list-item) to calculate the numbering in the marker.
    • https://drafts.csswg.org/css-lists/#propdef-list-style-type
  • (p4) I'd like to see a clear sample of the difference in behavior between counter-reset and counter-set.
  • (p5) In addition, I would like to see a more helpful example of how to use reversed().

It is my hope that the documentation will clearly explain why each browser behaves the way it does.

In particular, I think the following current statement is wrong.

The value to reset the counter to on each occurrence of the element. Defaults to 0 if not specified.

The latest version of Firefox doesn't seem to reset to on each occurrence of the element. This may just be because it resets the counter, but creates another instance, which makes it look like the counter is not being reset.

Related specs

  • https://www.w3.org/TR/css-lists-3/#counter-reset
  • https://drafts.csswg.org/css-lists/#counter-reset
  • w3c/csswg-drafts#4244
  • w3c/csswg-drafts#5477
  • https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#lists
  • https://drafts.csswg.org/css-lists/#propdef-list-style-type

Related links

  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1548753
  • #3737
  • #6360
  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1754521
  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1757269

What did you expect to see?

I don't know what the specs say about subtle nuances and what is the right way to behave.

item.title: [css-values-3] Content suggestion: Remove <length-percentage> and similar pages
item.content:encoded:
What is the new suggestion?

Remove https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/length-percentage and similar pages.

Why is it important or useful?

mdn/browser-compat-data#14971 is a PR to remove it in BCD, because support data is just the union of two other features. If we remove it from BCD, either the MDN page should be removed, or it includes the two compat tables for <length> and <percentage>.

Other supporting information

My weak opinion is that exposing these spec abstractions to readers is a bit weird, but that argument also applies to <length> and <percentage>. Perhaps they're useful to avoid spelling out all the allowed values for each property.

item.title: [cssom-view-1] Issue with "Document: scroll event": Example using rAF in scroll-event callbacks is outdated, and anti-performance
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/scroll_event

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The example using requestAnimationFrame in scroll event callbacks is totally outdated, it in fact anti-performance wise in these days.

Firing scroll events is aligned/defined in the HTML spec, all major browsers, Chrome, Safari and Firefox fire before processing requestAnimationFrame callbacks, so with the requestAnimationFrame callacks it just triggers queuing a redundant requestAnimationFrame callback and invoking the callback.

Specific section or headline?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/scroll_event#examples

What did you expect to see?

Scroll event handlers can be used without requestAnimationFrame callbacks.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I tested with a simple example having scroll event handler and requestAnimationFrame callbacks something like this;

window.addEventListener("scroll", e => {                                        
  console.log("got a scroll event on " + document.timeline.currentTime);        
});                                                                             
requestAnimationFrame(function rAF() {                                          
  console.log("got a rAF callback on " + document.timeline.currentTime);        
  requestAnimationFrame(rAF);                                                   
});

Thank you, MDN content editors.

item.title: [css-fonts-5] Issue with "@font-face/font-weight": Document <font-weight-absolute>{2}

I've only just started writing my first variable font CSS today, off the cuff, so I don't have an insight on the history of the spec / known browser quirks, but pretty soon I discovered that not mentioning a font-weight range in @font-face causes issues in Chrome and Safari.

item.title: [css-transforms-2, css-transforms-1] Issue with "transform": Need to clarify transform-function application in reverse order
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

It's not obvious or clear that the transform functions are effectively applied in reverse order, and that each represents a transform matrix applied to the initial vector of each of the four corners of the target.

In vector/matrix maths we write V(result) = M(1) M(2) V(initial). The assumed operator is 'matrix multiplication'. Thus we see that M(2) is applied first. A link to something explaining this would be useful.

If perspective() is one of multiple function values, it must be listed first.

Really? Surely it's just another matrix.

Specific section or headline?

n/a

What did you expect to see?

Some explanation of the maths, at least indicating that the transforms are applied in reverse order.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I studied mathematics at university.

item.title: [mediaqueries-4, css-conditional-3] Issue with "@media": Need more clarity re Level 4 v Level 3, browser compat, and broken links
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@media

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The link to the W3C CSS Level 3 spec is broken.

The link to your own CSS Level 3 archive (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Archive/CSS3) is also broken.

I think there needs to be more clarity on the page on the differences between Level 3 and Level 4, particularly regarding the not and or operators, and more particularly because AFAIK Firefox is the only browser that supports Level 4 here.

I think there should be more examples using the not and or operators for both Level 3 and Level 4. I have not come across the or operator before (in Level 3 one would use the comma operator).

The browser compatibility table should include whether Level 4 is supported for @media rules.

The browser compatibility table should include which media features are supported (not all support all). Some browsers will discard entire @media rules if they include an unsupported media feature.

Specific section or headline?

Various sections.

What did you expect to see?

Clearer guidance for developers.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Yes, multifariously. And from experience.

item.title: [notifications, cssom-view-1, service-workers-1, dom, pointerevents3] Better naming of pages
item.content:encoded:
A big step forward was made in #8351, but I'd like to propose this rule to page naming:

  1. If the item is available on the global, use the name. Eg:
    • ServiceWorkerGlobalScope.skipWaiting becomes skipWaiting.
  2. If the item is typically reached via properties reachable from the global, use that property chain, omitting the global.
    • Document.querySelector becomes document.querySelector.
    • CacheStorage.match becomes caches.match.
  3. If the item is an instance method/property, use the constructor name with the first set of caps lower-cased + the property name.
    • Element.getBoundingClientRect becomes element.getBoundingClientRect.
    • HTMLElement.offsetHeight becomes htmlElement.offsetHeight.
  4. If the item is a static method/property, use the constructor name + the property name.
    • Notification.requestPermission remains Notification.requestPermission.
  5. Otherwise, just use the name.
    • PointerEvent remains PointerEvent

item.title: [SVG11, css-masking-1] Deprecated Property on Documentation for SVG clipPath Element
item.content:encoded:
In the documentation for the SVG clipPath element (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Element/clipPath) the example uses the use element and the xlink:href attribute.

According to https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Element/use#attributes, the xlink:href attribute has been deprecated in favour of the href attribute.

Should this be corrected?

item.title: [html, cssom-view-1, dom, WebIDL-1, FileAPI, uievents, pointerlock-2] Remove alert() from live samples
item.content:encoded:
window.alert() doesn't work cross-origin in Chrome any more, meaning that any of our live samples that rely on alert() are now broken.

See also #7553.

This is (I think) all the live samples in Web/API that use alert() in a live sample:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/attr/localname
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/canvasrenderingcontext2d/addhitregion
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/document/querycommandstate
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/domexception/domexception
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/eventlistener
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/eventtarget/addeventlistener
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/file/name
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/keyboardevent/metakey
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/mouseevent
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/notifications_api/using_the_notifications_api
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/window/find
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/windoworworkerglobalscope/settimeout (fixed in #7560)

(I might have missed some).

We should replace all of these with some alternative. A common alternative is to write the output into an element in the example's document.

item.title: [css-lists-3] Issue with "counter-reset": the example is a bit confusing
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/counter-reset

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The example at the start of the article is a bit confusing.
See https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1717772 for details why.
The example kind of misleading since it's not how you would typically use nested counter scopes.
(I guess it was written before we changed CSS counters to be compatible with HTML list ordinals, which are now defined in terms of the built-in CSS list-item counter.)

Specific section or headline?

Did you test this? If so, how?

item.title: [html, selectors-4] :target doesn't work within shadow roots
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/:target

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Let's assume you have this Web Component:

let template = `
	<div>
		<a href="#message">Make the message red</a>
		<h2 id="message">Message in a bottle</h2>
	</div>
	<style>
		#message:target {
			color: red;
		}
	</style>
`;

customElements.define('my-component', class myElement extends HTMLElement {
	constructor() {
		super();
		let shadowRoot = this.attachShadow({ mode: 'open' });
		shadowRoot.innerHTML = template;
	}
});

This code fails to work because the event :target is missing in the root of the shadow.

Specific section or headline?

What did you expect to see?

I expected that :target would work inside the web components.
I expect the message to run red when clicking on the link.

Did you test this? If so, how?

scrollTop value is negative when display: flex and flex-direction: column-reverse used.

item.title: [cssom-view-1] Issue with "Document.elementFromPoint()": Add info about nodes dragged and their position in the DOM tree
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/elementFromPoint

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

We were using elementFromPoint for a node that can be dragged for the dragend event to find out which node is below the dragged node. In the recent Edge this works but in Firefox it does not. I assume that the cause is that a dragged node is

  • above the "node" document / window in firefox
  • above the current node below the dragged node in edge

We found a "fix" - instead of using the onDragEndEvent we can use onDropEvent. For the drop event document.elementFromPoint returns the expected node.

draggableNode.addEventListener("dragend", onDragEndEvent, false);


function onDragEndEvent(event)
{
     // returns html in firefox  but the node below in edge / 
     let elemBelow = document.elementFromPoint(event.clientX, event.clientY);
}

function onDropEvent(event)
{
    // i was wrong here 
}

Specific section or headline?

None. I suggest to add an additional information or a link to explain why document.elementFromPoint returns the html root for a dragged node

What did you expect to see?

For the dragend event i expected that firefox behaves like edge. That document.elementFromPoint return the node under the draggedElement at the moment the event dragEnd fires.
None the less i now understand that the drop event might be better suited.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I created a codepen https://codepen.io/codemuggle/pen/NWbQqOW
